subject: RE: [junit] Testing initial conditions
msgSnippet: There is only one unit of US currency, the Federal Reserve Note. That they are available on pieces of paper to represent multiples of that unit is a side
messageBody:
There is only one unit of US currency, the Federal Reserve Note. That
they are available on pieces of paper to represent multiples of that
unit is a side issue! :-)

Anyway ...

To my mind, our JUnit tests should check the API behaviour. This
includes normal or "happy path" usage and boundary condition behaviour.
The internal behaviour of the object is up to the object. JUnit doesn't
and shouldn't care about what did, did not or might have happened
between calling the method/constructor and getting a return. If the
internals of your object are complicated then consider breaking it into
a few smaller objects.

I would also strongly recommend using Exceptions to indicate internal
error conditions. They are much cleaner than arbitrary return values.

Simon

> > "My 1/50 of a unit of United States Federally-Issued currency. :-)"
>Which unit? :)
>
>Seriously though, I agree with Simon. However, if this state is
>necessary to be known to other objects I would suggest that the
>initialize not be in the constructor. If other objects must know about
>it's state, it's better to have those objects call the initialize()
>themselves. On the other hand, I don't think the internal state of an
>object should be publicized, as a general rule. So that might suggest
>that you provide better exception handling instead (or in addition to)
>the "newing" of an object.
>
>-jason
>
>-----Original Message-----
>From: Chappell, Simon P [mailto:simon.chappell@...]
>Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 12:51 PM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: RE: [junit] Testing initial conditions
>
>
>There is a school of thought that an object's API should never allow
>it's internal state to be made unstable/invalid/partially-updated. I
>would vote for doing whatever it takes to ensure that the initial state
>is valid and then use unit tests to ensure that it stays that way.
>
>My 1/50 of a unit of United States Federally-Issued currency. :-)
>
>Simon
